May 29 2005	Prime Real Estate ...	We planned a trip to Alaska, cruising out of San Francisco on May 16th.We wanted to attach a 3 day stay before the cruise. We chose Priceline, and what luck in getting the Radisson. The location was perfect. We used public transportation, walked many, many miles, bike the bridge and took a taxis to the ship ... all with the assistance of a well informed hotel staff at the Radisson, even during very busy moments in the small lobby area.Food of all prices and variety was available everywhere and with the convenient hotel entrance next to Pier 39, we could return quickly to the hotel room for a sweater, camera batteries, or the typical needs of a traveler enjoying fabulous seafood.We have used Priceline many times and always got excellent results, some hotels add a 'fee', not the Radisson ... we expected to be in a room somewhere near a storage closet. We were not surprised when our window opened to the second floor parking lot but beyond the parking facility was a spectacular view of Alcatraz ... we were happy.We had to wait for the cruise ship to get our beds turned down and get chocolates on our pillows but the Radisson offered SleepNumber beds ... first time we have had this luxury in a hotel!Why did we give this hotel an excellent rating? Dollar value, of course, but bottom line is: When we return to San Francisco, we will book directly to the Radisson, resisting the temptation to save a few dollars with Priceline and giving up the priceless value of location.

May 16 2005	Great location just perfect for a sightseeing holiday.	Dont listen to any of the bad reviews here, this hotel was perfect for a sightseeing holiday which is one of the main reasons why you would go to San Francisco. The rooms are basic but they have all the necessities you would need when staying somewhere. If you get a good room with a balcony you have a view over the bay which is a bonus.The location is perfect and is a walk away from most attractions, like Pier 39, which has many shops and restaurants, designed to meet many peoples needs. The must visit restaurant is Bubba Gump (based on the film Forest Gump for those of you who dont know). The food is great in there, as well as the service as they have some system where you show them a sign on your table when you want attention, plus it has great views of San Francisco bay while you eat. Plus Pier 39 is home to the famous sea lions, but be warned they really do smell.Even though the hotel doesnt have any where to eat there is an IHOP right next door so if you like the American style pancakes this is the place for you, visited most mornings for breakfast as the prices where very reasonable plus it filled you up right until lunchtime so you can concentrate on your sightseeing. The hotel is also a short distance away from the main cable car stop which will take you China Town and Union Square (a must for any shopperholics, nearly spent a whole day here after visiting China Town and afterwards had an excellent meal in the Cheesecake Factory on the top floor of Macys even though it took over 45 minutes to get a table it was well worth the wait).The staff at the hotel are friendly and are willing to help you with any questions you should have. The rooms are cleaned everyday and are to a good standard even though the dcor is a bit old. When there you should take the lift up Coit Tower to have an overview of the city and the walk up to the tower also has good view of the crooked part of Lombard Street. For tours to Alcatraz it is best to book the trip before you arrive as you may be disappointed as it gets booked up very quickly and the queues to buy tickets are very long. I booked the trip with a company called Travel San Francisco (www.travelsf.com) who combines the tour with either a tour of the city, a trip to Muir Woods and Sausilito or on its own. They were very helpful and quick with replying to my queries.All in all we had a fantastic time in San Francisco and would use this hotel again.

Feb 24 2005	It's okay	I stayed at the Radisson on the Wharf for 3 nights. Like all the previous reviews said, the location is great. Oct 22 2004	Embarrassed on our wedding night!!!	My Grandmother had bought my new husband and I a night at the Radisson in San Francisco for our wedding night as a wedding present. Since she lives in New Mexico with my parents she had to secure the room with her credit card over the internet and telephone, and they sent her numerous forms via regular mail for her to fill out to verify her identity, etc, so she could pay with the credit card without them actually having the card in their possession, as is their policy. So everything was supposedly ok and they told her that the room was paid for with her credit card. When we went to check out the next morning, they informed us we had a balance of $192! I said that the room was already paid for, it was a wedding gift from my grandmother and had been paid for months ago. They told us that they do not accept payment without having a credit card in their possession (even though my mom and granmother had done everything the hotel management told them to do to get around that policy, and it had all been approved!) They flat out refused to even call my mom and grandmother to try to get things straightened out! It was a very embarrassing situation, being in the lobby of the hotel on the day after our wedding, having to pay for our wedding present and having everyone in the lobby listening to the conversation as well. I don't think the staff handled the situation professionally at all. The lady at the front desk made us feel like we were some lowlife scum trying to skip out on the bill. Thank goodness we had the money to pay for it or I don't know what we would have done!!

Oct 19 2004	The Radisson Was Just Great!	The Radisson Hotel Fisherman's Wharf was great. I read all the negative reviews and was expecting to find this place somewhat below standard. We had previously stayed at the Sheraton (across the street from the Radisson) and the Hyatt and wanted to try something a little less expensive. What we found was a little older very clean hotel. The desk staff were very helpful and polite. The cleaning staff was outstanding. Our room was ready when we got to the hotel (4 hours before the normal check-in time of 3 PM). This was also Fleet Week which sees a big increase in bookings.The only things that were negative were the in-room safe didn't work and the buttons on the phone that allowed you to make a wake-up call didn't work. The safe wasn't a problem because we don't travel with valuables and we had to go to the front desk to ask for a wake up call. The lobby is nicely appointed. The rooms aren't large but they are clean and comfortable. The bathroom was a nice size with a good size counter top.There is an IHOP located on the property plus a Johnny Rockets at the end of the pool area.There is a private entrance to the Fisherman's Wharf area that is really a nice addition. You use your room key to open the locked security door.There is a Safeway super market two blocks south (across the street from the Sheraton. This place is really expensive but you can save a few bucks if you get one of their Safeway Club cards. You get the card from the cashier after you fill out a short form.There is also a Burger King near the Safeway that didn't accept American Express Travelers Checks (we found that strange). A taxi ride from the airport is expensive - it cost between $40 and $50 one way. The high end is due to the cab drivers taking the longer route to Fisherman's Wharf. We understand the city is trying to stop this practice.What it boils down to is this - the Radisson is all about location. If you love the area as we do you can't find a better location. We stayed a week and had a wonderful time. We would stay here again.

Sep 13 2004	$30 parking fees	Although Radisson hotel at fisherman's wharf has an excellent location, the rooms are small with a huge TV armoire with uncomfortable doors. Also, I was not expecting a $30 parking fee per day. At least they should have included it in the orbitz price. It meant an increase of 25% !.

Sep 5 2004	Decent hotel Fantastic location	This hotel is in a great location - right in the heart of Fisherman's Wharf and overlooking Pier 41. . We stayed here for three nights in September 2004. I had read the reviews and was a little concerned that the hotel would be below standard. It wasnt. Rooms were of a decent size - with 2 double beds, armchair, TV, bathroom, fridge and safe. Check in was efficient.Dont expect any views of the Wharf unless you pay for them. We got a web rate on the hotel which was $109 per room per night which was excellent value for the location. They do charge $28 per night for car parking but this is the going rate for 24hr parking in the area. Its a good place for families as it is so close to everything at Pier 39, in the wharf and the Alcatraz ferry. The cable car stop is a few blocks away and there is also a Johnny Rockets and IHOP on site for breakfasts...(which pleased our 15 and 11 year olds!)The pool was heated some of the time but not all. Its fine for a dip but the pool area doesnt get a great deal of sun so it can be quite cold. If you have a car, we strongly recommend doing the 49-mile drive around San Francisco. Its a great way to see all the main sights and is well signposted by blue and white seagull signs around the city.

Aug 31 2004	Very Noisy Room but great location	Spent 3 nights at Radisson. We really loved the location of the hotel right by the Wharf, however the hotel room was very small and our room was located on the street side (right hand corner of hotel) which was very noisy. We loved the location, yes it is touristy, but it was a fun location to be in. The hotel doesn't have a restaurant, but there is a small coffee cart in the lobby and an IHOP right down the block, plus with Pier 39 across the street many breakfast spots available. Aug 23 2004	horrible hotel	Stayed here three nights in Aug. 04. Location is the only positive thing I found here. Hotel rooms while clean are very small, doubles only no queen beds, beds were small and uncomfortable, we had to order a rollaway which they charged $15. per night for and had to squeeze it in between the two doubles. Front desk personal are of very little help with information as all the ones we talked with were from a foreign country with little knowledge of s.f. When we inquired about the cable car the girl informed us that though she had lived in the city for 10 years she had NEVER ridden on it, maybe management can spring one day for a trip for the employees on one of the best known sightseeing rides in the world so that they can answer questions. What of the concierge you may ask, well when there was one availabe their knowledge was'nt that much better than the desk personal. She sold us a day long city tour and told us to eat a good breakfast (which you have to go out of the hotel for, as they have no restaurant) because the trip was all day and we would not have any stops to eat at, turns out there are two stops in the morning and a lunch break of at least 1 &1/2 hrs in between and another stop on the afternoon trip.Security at the hotel is very laxs and my wife and daughter were followed to the elevator by four street kids who jumped off the elevator when my son and I got on before they could. The wharf section of the city is very touristy, good place to buy souveneirs and really smells bad. Parking is $15 per day and is very limited, after returning one night we had to circle around for 1/2 hr before finally squeezing our suv into a compact spot. Much better choices for the money in frisco try the nob hill area or Saulaslito only 20 min. drive. and much nicer.

Aug 16 2004	Great location!	Spent one night here, before going to the Napa Valley. We had a room on the 3rd floor directly facing the water. Great view of Alcatraz and Pier 39. Really great view. My only complaint would be the tiny cramped bathroom. The view and location more than made up for the bathroom!

Aug 10 2004	Okay Room/Great Location	We stayed at this Raddison last week. The room was very small. (My daughter said she felt like she was on a cruise ship.) Aug 4 2004	Very Disappointed with this hotel!	This Raddison does not measure up even to Motel 6 standards! Upon checking in, our room was not ready and we waited several hours to get our keys. When they did clean it, they would only leave 2 washcloths and towels even though we have a family of 4. I left a note to the maid along with a nice tip. The maid would take the tip and not leave the extra towels/washcloths. The staff acted as if they could care less about their service. Jul 28 2004	AWESOME Location	Stayed here with my boyfriend from out-of-state over the 4th of July weekend. Jun 29 2004	Great Location	Great Location. Central to all main San Francisco sites. Loved the access from the courtyard of the hotel direct to the Wharf. Found hotel staff to be knowledgeable and friendly. Rooms are a bit on the small side, our party consisted of 2 adults and 2 children. But for the location and proximity for a reasonable price it was worth the close quarters. When ready to leave the city, the hotel is near several major car rental agencies.

Jun 20 2004	Good Hotel with a Great Location in Tight Quarters	Location, location, location! The Radisson Hotel Fishermans Wharf is located right on the Waterfront, next to the Pier 39 Entertainment Complex. The Radisson is in a fully renovated 5-story 1950s building. Hotel dcor is best described as modern contemporary, and the property was fully renovated in 2000. There is an on-site Parking Garage ($25/day) with tight spaces.The front entrance to the Radisson is off Beach Street (directly across from the Sheraton). You walk into the small lobby decorated in earth tones and a nice granite tile floor. The front desk is on the side wall and there are large glass doors leading to the pool courtyard. The staff was professional, but lacking warmth. Check-in was easy and uneventful and we were off to our room. We went to the elevator lobby and up to the 5th floor.The corridors in the hotel are tight. Halls are well lit and decorated nicely, but there is barely enough room for opposing traffic to get by. Our room was a south facing room (city view). The room was a little smaller than average, but was quite attractive. All furnishings were in good condition and the drapes opened up to a delightful city view. Our room looked out across the Sheraton Hotel and up the hillsides of the city and Coit Tower. Trolleys passed below continuously on Beach Street (which my son thoroughly enjoyed), but this caused no disturbance to us. There were two full size beds in our Double Room configuration. Bedding was clean and comfortable, very characteristic for a 3-star property. Bathrooms were very clean, but on the small side. Rooms include coffeemakers, in-room safes, Two line phones with voicemail, dataports, alarm clock radios, ironing boards, hairdryers, PPV movies and video games.The hotel has no dining in the facility. This is odd for a Radisson, but with all the dining options nearby at Pier 39, this is not a problem. In fact, I dont think I would have eaten there anyway. The Concierge in the Lobby was very helpful in suggesting restaurants. Unfortunately, no restaurant means no room service. But San Francisco is famous for its take out and delivery, so take advantage of that.There is an outdoor heated pool in the central courtyard. It was very pleasant, and there is also a fitness center available for your use.In closing, the Radisson Hotel Fishermans Wharf is a nice place, with a primo location. It is the only hotel on the waterfront in the Fishermans Wharf area. The Sheraton is only one block farther, but all the others are a good walk away. For the money, the Radisson shines. But dont be confused, it is only a 3-star hotel. If you need more in a hotel, I would recommend the Sheraton or the Hyatt.

Jun 8 2004	Great Location	This hotel is right on the wharf, well the nearest. So its just a case of walking round the corner where you can take a trip to Alcatraz, a bay cruise or take in the not so wonderful stench of the sea lions! I booked the hotel on the internet and filled in the form to request a smoking room, not realising that California are totally against this bad habit, I consequently did not get a smoking room as the hotel has only 8 such rooms and they were already booked, so dont expect too much, all hotels which state they have both types of rooms probably dont have too many, as smoking is not encouraged in this part of the world not even in bars. The hotel is very clean and has large rooms but does not have a breakfast room, there is a cart selling coffee and pastries etc but its not cheap. A IHOP is located next door which always seemed popular, a whole airline crew came in there the morning I was there, complete with their luggage. Its pancakes with everything so if you dont like them you can go to Johney Rockets for a real American diner experience, you would believe you were back in the 50's, this is located out the door from reception past the very small pool and then you walk in the diner through its back door, when you leave, through the front door you are on the wharf! Round the corner from the right of reception is a 24/7, here you can pour your own coffee-around 12-20 different varieties, always piping hot, very good and inexpensive, they have a selection of cakes and pastries but its take away, also I dont think you could ask for anything they didnt have here in this shop, wine, sweets, chocolate, toiletries. We walked a few blocks to the Cannery and the trolleys leave for Union Square area a further block, the view from here of Golden Gate bridge is great. Travelled first weekend in May and never saw a cloud, photos are fab, blue skies for 4 days. Fishermans Wharf is the best location unless you want to spend yout time shopping for designer gear in Union Square.

May 31 2004	Decent Hotel Great Location	As others have described, the hotel itself is nothing special with pretty much run of the mill rooms and amenities. The location is this hotel's major asset. It is right in the heart of Fisherman's Wharf and a great "home base" for visiting San Fran. This was our first trip to San Fran and we wanted to do all of the "touristy" things so this hotel was great for us. You're close to all of the Wharf's attractions (sea lions, boat tours, etc), plus you can easily jump a trolley or cable car within a couple blocks and get anywhere in the city. Definitely try to get a "bay view" if you can, otherwise you might just as well stay at one of the other off-the-water places depending on prices, as this hotel is nothing special without the view. The hotel is shaped like a big fork with three "tines" pointing toward the water, if you can get one of the end rooms (like we did) you will love the view. Our room was just off the water with a great view of the bay. We could even see the sea lions at Pier 39 from our window (room 4112). In summary, we had a great experience but I believe that we also kind of lucked out and got one of the best rooms available (top floor, right off the water). If you can get a good price and a bay view it's a good deal, otherwise you may want to look elsewhere. Also, I work for a large company and was able to get a great corporate rate with parking and breakfast included. We paid $107 per night. If you work for a large corporation you might check to see if you can get a better than advertised rate.

May 28 2004	Not up to Radisson standards - like a Motel 6	My flight arrived at noon but even though rooms were available I couldn't check in till 3pm because of hotel "policy." I have stayed at numerous Radisson Hotels and have been happy but this hotel does not deserve the Radisson name.Sorry Radisson but you need to junk this place or change its' name so you are not associated with it.

Apr 20 2004	Comfort Great Location 	Our stay at The Raddison at Fisherman's Wharf from April 2nd through April 7th was very pleasant. Oct 16 2003	Convenient Location	We chose this hotel because of its very convenient location, virtually across the street from Piers 39 & 41 of Fisherman's Wharf. This is Tourist Central in S.F., whether you want to shop, see Alcatraz, cruise the bay, admire the sea lions,or take a bus tour--it's all there outside your door. You don't spend much time in the hotel. The lobby is small, with fee-based internet available, and a coffee cart (this Starbuck's lover found the coffee surprisingly good) and somewhat helpful concierge. Front desk staff seemed disinterested/on verge of being annoyed every time I dealt with them--maybe they are overworked. the 2 Elevators are independently programmed, therefore they are slow and inefficient. There is a small but servicable fitness center, and accessible through the pool courtyard is a diner style restaurant (which was blasting music way too loud for breakfast!). The pool courtyard is lovely, with a garden area; however, even though we were in S.F. during supposedly their warmest season (October), it was far too cold for outdoor swimming or, for that matter, sitting in the shady courtyard) We paid about $111 per night, plus $23 per day parking, for a room that was clean, spacious, and afforded us a nice view of Nob Hill and the south of the city. In short, the Radisson was all that we were looking for, and no more.

Sep 25 2008 	the rudest experience I have ever had	I have stayed here once before and it was ok. The place is very old and run down. I believe it is not the same ownership though.I didn't sleep very well because I had forgotten my own pillows and their pillows are completely flat. When I awoke the following morning I got up and went to Ocean Beach, which was my whole purpose for being in the city. I lost myself in the walk as the ocean is captivating. As I arrived back to the motel on foot I was looking in the windows for check out time and so nothing posted anywhere. I looked in the room and on my receipt which was just my credit card receipt. There was nothing saying when check out is, nor was I told when checking in. I figured with most places it is between 11 and 12. It was 10:45 so I decided to jump in the shower. I thought I heard the phone ring while in the shower but was not sure. Once out of the shower did the usual girl thing and blow dried my hair. Once done I heard this knocking on the door and someone saying something about check out but could not quite understand. I called back that I wasn't ready yet. Within 10 mins there was another knock on the door by the lady manager, I presume. She begins yelling at me to "open this door right now". I said, "do you mind if I put my shirt on first." Sep 25 2006 	A Different Kind of Stay	This is not a motel for the weak of heart. It is, in all senses, that sort of Raymond Chandler-esque "sleazy dive" that is only missing the gangsters and hard-boiled detectives. But it is a place to stay, reasonably priced, and no more outrageous than some that are far worse. My stay was shortly after the current owners took over, and they did their best, but it was clear that being hoteliers was not in their blood, and that their "vision" of running this place was flawed. I had stayed previously (2001-2002) when the previous owners, who had a clue, still ran it.Nonetheless, the night I arrived was the worst storm to hit the SF Peninsula in a long time, with Beach Avenue closed, and police clearing people off the beach for safety sake. Winds and rain, lightning and thunder, all crashing with the waves not 500 feet from my door and window.It was the most spectacular stay in a motel I have ever had. Second floor, watching California weather at its most magnificent, from a vantage point that I would have never thought possible.It is rundown, a bit dingy, and perhaps not a five-star luxury palace for those who wish to be pampered.But for those who want to experience a classic 1930s motel, in the middle of the Sunset District, with a western view that is to die for, there is little better than this.And for the full effect? Pick up a Raymond Chandler novel to read before bedtime instead of watching the tube, or book a room when you know a storm is coming. I'm going to be in SF in the next few months, and have no qualms about booking another room there.

Aug 7 2006	Horrendous Motel	You would do much better to sleep out on the sidewalk in front of this place than to pay money and check into one of their rooms. These things however, pale when laid up against what ensued on my stay there. My girlfriend and i checked in for a week and after accomodating the dismal condition of the room...settled in unfortunately. On waking up the third morning we were both covered with what we thought were mosquito bites. Through that day...these bites kept increasing and encroaching in intensity and by the fourth morning...we were both in great duress and shock from these bites which had turned into aggravated welts. I checked the bedding more closely and found little points of fresh blood stains on the sheets and a little dead bug of a type which i hadn't seen before. The welts were running across my body in long staright rows that were deep and red and i was trying to control a feeling of panic. My girlfriend's face was covered with them. She ended up with around 200 bites and i had about 150. Upon doing some investigating...i found that this was a bed bug infestation. As someone who's made a living on the road for 35 years...this was the worst thing I've ever encountered in a sleeping establishment. We checked out on that fourth morning and i required medical treatment and steroids to overcome the danger of these bites. The physical scars are still with both of us six months later. If i had a choice between sleeping on a park bench or sleeping at Roberts By The Beach Motel in San Francisco...i'd take the bench with no second thoughts. Horrible experience indeed.

The lady at the desk said it may have been related to the the recent renovations, but she did make a note of it. And, my roommate was awakened by women outside the door at 3 AM yelling obscenities at a man. "Breakfast" consisted of 2 pre-wrapped pastries. Sep 4 2009 	Stay here if you ONLY need a bed close to Moscone Center.	We chose the SF Marriott cuz of the easy walk to the trade show and to host meetings w/partners and customers. If you need small meeting rooms with simple catering, find another hotel. They only offer sleeping rooms with attached meeting suites, unless you want a Ballroom. Coffee is $100 per gallon (so is tea!). Sodas are $6.50ea. When they say you're only charged for what you drink, it's a lie. We shopped at the local Walgreen's for affordable snacks and drinks and used VERY FEW of their catered beverages (only used by our visitors). They charged us MORE that what we originally ordered, couldn't tell us why, and refused to do anything about it. The morning setup folks showed up late, so catering wasn't ready at 8am. When we reiterated the need for 7:45 setup, the next morning they showed up at 6:45 and woke up our CEO. Another time, room service decided to add ice to the setup and made so much noise, it stopped our meeting while she was escorted from the room. I asked for a handicap room for our guy in a wheelchair and they gave him a room with a step in shower, even after I called and verified they had plenty of rooms with wheel in showers. Several of our employees noticed their stuff had been rifled through. This hotel has had so much convention business it no longer knows anything about customer service. The Sales Staff doesn't know about its Suites and they make it impossible to see the Suites prior to your event....they won't even send pictures. They neglected to tell us the Luxury suite (@$50 cheaper per nite) was much bigger than the Marriott Suite and had a half bath off the meeting area. Always make sure the suite you have your major meetings in has a bathroom off it, so the person in the sleeping room (in this case, our CEO!) won't have to share a bathroom with all your visitors. Had we been able to preview the rooms, we would have caught this faux pas. It's a good thing our CEO is flexible and understanding!The sales staff is never around to help. We are a small company and we didn't ask for much...just a couple of nice rooms to meet with customers and some beverage catering. What a nightmare! Next year we will be at a much smaller hotel that appreciates our business. I recommend you do too!

Sep 3 2009 	Comfy bed clean nice views	We spent 5 nights to see the city for the first time. The hotel is centrally located to all trolley lines and Muni stops. We were all over the place, so it was nice to come home to a comfortable room. All the rooms have a decent view, whether it is of the city or the harbor. The 39th floor has a wonderful bar and restaurant. It is totally worth it to go see and have a drink or a dessert. The food is pretty basic, so dinner might be better spent elsewhere. We are platinum members of Marriott, so the concierge lounge was great for breakfast in the morning. I would say the downsides of the hotel is that it caters to conventions. Oh, and if you rent a car, there is a Hertz in the hotel, EXCEPT, the hotel valet charges you $10 to go get the car for you.. that was a rip off. Aug 31 2009 	Thieves - a Well Organized Bunch	While staying at the San Francisco Marriot, my iPhone and some other items were stolen from my vehicle left to their valet parking. Trying to resolve the issue with the hotel and their valet parking service definitely gave me the impression that the theft and cover-up were well organized.It was my fault to slip the brand new iPhone 3GS, which ran out of battery on my way to the hotel, into the console compartment and forget to take it when I handed the car to valet parking.The next morning when the valet brought out the car, I immediately found that the phone and other items were missing. I reported to the parking manager and was told to wait for their investigation results. From then on every time I asked for an update, I was told that either the parking manager in charge was not in, or they were still investigating. He called hotel security but told me that the hotel could not do anything about it, because "parking was operated by a different company and we had to wait for their investigation results." The next day when I checked out, the parking manager told me that "we reviewed the video tapes and questioned employees, and found no suspicious activities". The only thing he could do was to help me filling out a claim form, which I knew was going to be denied.A week later, I received a letter from the parking company. The letter states that guests should not leave valuable items in vehicles and they are not responsible for anything lost.My impression from the ordeal: San Francisco Marriot has thieves in their parking staff. Aug 27 2009 	Great Stay! I'd Go Back For Sure!	We celebrated our 30th Anniversary with a trip to San Francisco last week. I chose this hotel for location - and it was perfect! The Westfield Mall is a 1/2 block away - great shopping and a really good food court. If we get to come back to San Fran...this is where we're staying!!

Aug 26 2009 	Convenient location not ideal for business travel	The location is good if you're going to the Moscone Center or anywhere else in SoMa. Aug 17 2009 	Couldn't have been better	We stayed here for the SF Half Marathon, and it couldn't have been better (except if the parking was free or less expensive). Aug 14 2009 	We are suppose to go back next aug.--uuuggghh!	I hope the hotel managment reads this review!!!!Rooms::: For a hotel that is known for it's windows--please clean them. Awful.I think moths have raided the hotel and I pray they didn't get into my clothes and that I am bringing them home with me.SEROUSLY-your beds may have bedbugs. I have 2 bites that I am going to the doctor for tomorrow and if I find out they are bedbugs--you will hear from me. That is not cool.Why have you cut back on the cleaning? Cleaning is the most important part of a room....right? The vents, bedding, pillows and floor were dirty. Gross! I called the front desk 2 times to get fresh bedding and never got it. We stayed 5 nights and never once got clean sheets or bedding. Is this legal? Hotel::: PLEASE keep the bar open when there is a large convention. I promise you will make money. Ask the group staying if they think their employees would all go up to the bar --and then staff it and keep it open--otherwise we will all hang out in the lobby. WHY-WHY-WHY-WHY is it so hard to offer wi-fi in the room for free? Seriously, in todays world it's a must for us to stay there. You probably lose more customers due to the fact that you don't have it then it could ever cost you to have it. The most important thing for me is a clean room. I hope all people who stay at your hotel will review on this point. I hope that you will work for the next year to improve this. I pray that you don't have moths and bedbugs as I suspect you do. You are a Marriott-act like one. Cleanliness should be #1. Service should be #2. Rooms should be important too....please make them comfortable with towels and clean windows. Is that too hard for a Marriott? If one person reads this review and does not book with you then it was not worth it for you to NOT pay the housekeeper to clean. People do read reviews and I hope every person who reads this calls you directly to ask if you have changed your cleaning policy, if you have checked for moths and bedbugs and if you have cleaned your windows in the past month. It was a beautiful week when we were there and when you looked out our dingy windows it looked rainy and dark. It was sunny. I'm serious when I say that there was evidence of dirt in the vents, moth bites on the furniture and I pray the bites I got were not from bedbugs. Either way they were from my stay and that is gross. I pray the ice I got was clean. I didn't even think of that until after I drank my drink. Travelers, if your company books you here BRING FOOD and bleach wipes to do your own cleaning. If they improve on these items I would love for someone to write a review and tell me as I am forced to stay next Aug. with work again. Here's the good: Location - The hotel is in a great location. Aug 12 2009 	A 3 star at best!	With so many options in San Francisco, I booked with the Marriott San Francisco for a couple of reasons:1) The location was central to wll that we wanted to do2) The senior discount (my mom qualified) offered a good rate3) It wasn't as hip as some of the other choices in the area (W or Intercontinental) which is a negative for some in my party, including 3 children4) I tend to be brand loyal, as a Marriott Elite memberHowever, when I return to the city, I will look elsewhere for a couple of reasons:1) The room preferences I have (listed on my profile) were ignored. I requested a refrigerator, high floor and extra towels. I received none of these.2) My mom needed a soda when we got back to the hotel from the Giants game. it was 11:10pm. Not late for a city, right? Well, the vending machines listed as available on each floor, have been removed. The gift shop was closed. Room service was closed. The front desk clerk directed us to a 7-11 a good 10 minute walk away on Market St. I'm glad I wasn't alone, as I would have felt uncomfortable if I were. For a 4 star hotel in a major city, not being able to get something as simple as a Diet Coke after 11pm is an issue. God forbid I needed something more than that.3) By the time I got back from the 7-11, I wanted to head up to their view lounge with my husband for a drink, yet they closed at midnight! Once again, I expected more from the hotel in this respect. 4) The in room coffee was a joke. The quality was awful, with powdered creamer and Sweet and Low only. I travel with my mom a lot, and anything that is provided in-room saves me time and money, without having to venture out to get what she needs. 5) A fire drill exercise was conducted starting at 8am! The plusses of the hotel included:1) The beds were comfortable.2) The location was good if you were on foot, not so much with a car.3) The check-in and out were easy and painless4) They had an indoor pool and whirlpool for the kids.While the hotel might meed the needs of most travelers, for me, I will venture elsewhere next time.

Aug 9 2009 	Time for a Refresh	The location of this property is definately fantastic. Easy access to the cable cars, the BART station, and the Caltrain station. The halls are drab (no artwork or color), the guestrooms don't have wireless internet (really?? even most basic service hotels have wireless these days!), and the food was just ok.Service was pretty good. Staff was pleasant. However, when I checked in there was a room service tray belonging to the previous occupant outside my door and it stayed there for nearly 24 hours. Aug 7 2009 	Excellent Location Friendly staff and Good Value!	This is great hotel to base a family trip to San Francisco. Only 2 minutes from the largest Nordstrum shopping Mall in the world, a further minute to the Powell Cable Car Station which for $5 will whisk you all the way to the Wharf. Even though everything is on your doorstep, the hotel does not feel over busy as some central city based hotels can do. The staff were 'super' friendly, the rooms were normal fare for Marriott, nice decor, good size and clean, a proper 4 star hotel. To eat with a family at the Hotel is expensive, that goes for breakfast or dinner, however you are spoilt for choice of restaurants on your doorstep so we didn't bother. The pool is a little small and is indoor, but at least they have one, many don't..Free WiFi in the bar, although we didn't see this advertised anywhere.The best feedback I can give is that I'd return here in a flash.....

Aug 3 2009 	Moths have hit this hotel	I'm writing this review while in my room on my last night in the hotel. I'll start with the positive elements of the San Francisco Marriott. The location is GREAT. It's walking distance to the major shopping areas (Westfield Mall, Union Square, etc.) and to Moscone Center. The rooms are large (although this isn't a major consideration for me). The cheese plate is excellent, and the room service prices are good for SFO.That being said, this hotel is aging poorly--and the management hasn't invested in keeping it up. My major complaint is the extremely poor housekeeping (which is probably driven by cost-saving measures by the management company). There are several things that lead to this suspicion: (1) short time spent actually cleaning the room--I'll get into the details below, (2) two towels/king size room, and--most egregiously, in my mind--turning off the air conditioning EVERY DAY and ignoring my preferences.First, from an investment perspective: (1) the phone by the bed was not functional, (2) the windows were so covered with grime on the outside that it was hard to tell if it was actually foggy, or if it was just the dirt, (3) the furniture was moth-bitten, (4) the linens were moth-bitten, (5) the bathroom amenities were minimal (only shampoo, conditioner, and lotion), (6) room service doesn't serve during lunch or anything after 11:00 p.m., and (7) there was NO wireless internet access in the room (you actually had to connect with a 2.5 foot cable to a modem)--so much for relaxing on the bed.Housekeeping was ridiculous. I'm on an expense account, so I'm not a penny pincher when it comes to tipping for good service. Started out with a $5 tip. Bad service. Bumped it up to $10 on the second night to see if it made a difference. Nope. Air conditioning turned off every day. Ice bucket NEVER emptied. Bed linens not changed once during a five-night stay (with no instructions on "energy" (read: cost) saving initiatives). Bathroom coated with scum regardless of how many nights I was here.Bottom line, I understand the desire to save costs. However, there are enough hotels out there looking to 'customize your stay' that I'd look for a property that charges the same amount but has a better in-room experience.

Jul 18 2009 	This Marriott's slip is showing!	Belt-tightening has caused Marriott to shut down room service at 11PM leaving nowhere in the hotel to find a morsel to eat except for the tidbits in your room costing at least $4 each plus 20% "restocking fee"??? and tax. Not even a vending machine! The weary traveler arriving late is directed to a diner about 1 block away. You need an armed guard to get even that far. After the sun goes down the streets are inhabited by pimps, druggies, and ladies of the night. In a further effort to economize, the Marriott offers nowhere to eat in the hotel between 11AM and 5PM. Bring your own lunch, folks!!

Jul 18 2009 	Comfortable Stay	Our room was attractive, clean, and a nice size with HDTV, good lighting for reading, and a great bathroom. The comfortable bed had a feather comforter which was cozy but a little warm for this time of year. The hotel staff was friendly and helpful. There was a nice view of the SOMA area from our room. Since we got a good travel package deal on our room, we felt it was a great value for the money paid. The only snafu was the high-rise elevator didn't function one day because of the warm (!) day in SF. We didn't have to walk up to the 30th floor as they let us use the staff elevators! Have a drink in the bar on the 39th floor to enjoy the view.

Jul 12 2009 	Large Spacious Rooms and Superbly Located	As a Platinum Marriott member, I'm quite brand-loyal but have recently become disillusioned with the quality of several large-city Marriotts at which I've stayed. I'm delighted to say that the SFO Marriott reminded me of why I chose Marriott in the first place.The rooms - and this is the second time I've stayed here, the first when I had no status with Marriott, so it seems to be fairly standard - are very large, especially for an inner-city property. The working desk was very large and the chairs/table/bench were all very intuitively located within the room, so it felt very comfortable. Typically luxurious Marriott bedding and nice linens. Massive windows for natural light, with proper blackout curtains so you can sleep in if you're lucky enough to have a morning off. And thankfully this venue doesn't have that dreadful Citrus range of Marriott Bath and Body Works toiletries - the range here was creamy and herby rather than smelling like commerical cleaning products.The real bonus of this property is the location! Within a five minute walk of all the downtown shopping you could possibly want, and only a short walk to the BART if you want to go further afield. I travel about 50% of the time and would be dead if I ate hotel food every day/night. So the other thing I hugely appreciate about this property is the proximity to the wonderful Bristol Farms supermarket (in the shopping centre about three doors down). Amazing pre-prepared food from sushi to hot meals, a full grocery store complete with marvelous produce. The Marriott will provide an in-room refrigerator at no charge, so unlike many venues you can self-cater with some healthy food with a minimum of hassle.  At night there's the usual array of homeless around the venue , but in downtown San Francisco this is pretty standard. They're going to be outside all your shopping venues, so you're going to deal with it anyway. It's not dangerous - more a nuisance.The concierge lounge is lovely, with the usual array of teas, coffees, and a decent breakfast. One of the better breakfast services I've experienced. Fruit, yoghurt, eggs, plenty of breads and bagels etc. Shame the same can't be said of the evening service. The chicken strips disappeared and were not replenished after the first 45 minutes. So if you came after work (who's ever done with work by 5pm when travelling?) there was really nothing left except some mangy veggie leftovers and well-used dressing. The spring rolls were more plentiful, largely because nobody ate them. Oily, revolting and really shouldn't be there. When I asked about the chicken, the concierge (who was generally delightful but missed the mark on this particular issue) said "You just need to get here earlier!". The service is meant to go from 5.30 to 7pm (from memory) so this was a bit rough, in my view, for 6.10pm when I arrived.The in-house restaurant is OK, but has a limited selection, especially if you don't want fish, seafood or steak. There's plenty of choice around the hotel, and I'd strongly recommend the Bistro (Annabelle's) across the street - superb European quality food at reasonable restaurant prices. Ignore the bar, which looks divey, and head straight to the tables - you won't be disappointed. I had two appetizers for dinner - carpaccio and black bean soup - both of which were superb. And the wine list is quite good.Large rooms and you couldn't ask for a more convenient location. Highly recommended. I'm currently staying at another Marriott inner-city property (Philadelphia which I shall review when I check out in a week's time) and it's utterly hideous. This prompted me to go online and positively review San Francisco. It really is an excellent property.

Jul 11 2009 	Average at best paying purely for location	The lobby, service and overall cleanliness of this hotel are fine, and really you cannot beat the location of this hotel in San Francisco. However I couldn't help myself while staying here for a few days for a conference (and knowing the nightly rate), realizing that I would never pay this much for the quality of the hotel. The room and overall feel of the hotel all seemed outdated and rather early 90's nouveux riche; kind of like trying to be the cool, hip and fancy hotel, but falling well behind the times. My suggestion would be to find a more unique hotel in a decent location and save a chunk of money.
Jul 11 2009 	A very good hotel	We have stayed at the Marriott at least four times while in SF for a long weekend. It is good hotel for a three day weekend in SF.

Jul 7 2009 	Nice stay overall...Just beware of not answering your wake up call	Stayed at the hotel for 5 nights last week(6/27 to 7/2) while at a conference. Hotel is very nice and room was in very good condition. Stayed in the low rise section of the hotel(7 floors) and never waited more than a few seconds for an elevator. I know it is not an easy job to keep clean, but the windows were filthy(not that my view was that great, but still). I did not eat at the hotel at all during my stay. Went up to the bar at the top of the hotel one night for a couple of drinks. Outstanding views of the city. Did not have a car, but I noticed the hotel parking was $50+ per day. Many restaurants and stores within a few blocks. No wireless access in the hotel rooms, not even for a fee.Now to my big complaint...One morning I did not get my wake-up call. After I woke up late, I was in the bathroom and someone started pounding(I mean pounding) on my door repeatedly. I got out of the bathroom, answered the door and found a hotel security guard there. He proceeds to rudely blurt out "You didn't answer your wake up call and we wanted to make sure you weren't dead". Before I could say anything, he turns around and walks away. I called the front desk and they said this was hotel policy. I asked if it was hotel policy to have the guard say "I wanted to make sure you weren't dead" to which they replied that they will talk to the guard.
Jul 6 2009 	Clean and Quiet	Hotel was lovely, clean, quiet and safe. Location was perfect, less than block away from cable car turnaround. Would stay there again.

Jul 1 2009 	OK for biz not for fun	We actually did not stay at this Marriott the night we had reservations with a friends and family discount, we walked around the corner to the Palace Hotel instead. Jun 14 2009 	First choice for San Francisco downtown!	I've stayed at the Marriott a few times now in San Francisco. While it's not the best hotel I've ever stayed in there's very little to fault with it in my opinion. It has a great location right next to the Moscone Centre on one side and downtown on the other. I wouldn't consider staying anywhere else.The lobby was being refurbished during my stay in April 08 but this has now been completed and the hotel lobby is once again large, bright and airy. One thing to note is that this is a very large hotel with lots of people around at all times - I personally like this and find the staff still give great service. The hotel seems to be used quite a bit with conference delegates.The rooms are of a good size with the usual Marriott comfortable beds and large LCD TVs. Room service is quick and they provide a good selection of tasty meals. The restaurant is good for a quick bite to eat at lunchtime and also has a great selection for breakfast.My only slight criticism is the lack of wifi in the rooms. I use the wired internet connection but this can't be used with devices such as the iPhone.While at the hotel make sure you check out the bar on the top floor - the views are spectacular.

Jun 7 2009 	My new favorite hotel in San Francisco	I had such a great experience at the Marriott San Francisco. My husband and I went to the city for my 30th birthday, we stayed at the new Intercontinental on Howard the night before. I got a Saturday night stay for $103 plus tax through Marriott's website. The check in experience was one of the best ever, we were offerred an upgrade for $20, but when I opted out, the desk guy gave us a room on the 26th floor anyway. We had a great view of the city and a spacious room. The food and cocktails at The View lounge on the 39th floor was fantastic. We had the antipasti tray that was awesome, with wonderful flat bread, fancy salami and cured meats, cheese, olives, sundried tomateos ($14). I had a signature drink, the Crystal Slipper that was tasty and stout ($14). The chairs and couches are plush, looking out right over the city and Bay. The waitresses were so nice and attentive, very down to Earth. The heavenly beds good to sleep-in on a Sunday morning. Then I hit the gym, did some laps in the perfect temperature pool, and relaxed in the jacuzzi. The gym is great, personal TVs on each machine, lots of new LifeFitness equipment and weights. The Intercontinental was also great, but was more expensive: $119 for Friday night, $137 for saturday, and their resaturant is very pricey. Our room was bigger at the Marriott too. For my money, I'd rather go back to the Marriott, it's a better value.Park right across the street at the 5th and Mission Yerba Buena garage, $30 for 12-24 hours.

Jun 5 2009 	Really Great....	What can I say...my favorite hotel in San Francisco...and I've stayed at 5 thus far. A bit expensive but great rooms, great service and great location...Oh and a great lounge on the top floor with an AMAZING view of the city. Great place to stay.

May 19 2009 	Nice hotel	The hotel is in a great area for exploring the city. May 13 2009 	Great location super value perfect for families 55 South St SFO	Great location, super value, perfect for families - we stayed laster at the Grand Hyatt on Union Square and actually felt this was more convenient and roomy - esp for the shopping. Starbucks on ground floor.

May 11 2009 	Avoid this place at all costs	My husband and I traveled to the west coast for a family reunion. We decided to make a vacation out of it and spent 4 days in gorgeous San Francisco. But our trip didn't start off that great. We had reserved that hotel because of the indoor pool; we found out it was being serviced and we would not be able to use it or the jacuzzi during our stay. The clerk didn't even apologize, and why didn't I get an email letting me know ahead of time that the hotel would be partially under construction. Then, we were mortified that when we arrived at the hotel, at midnight, there was a half empty bottle of water on the floor next to the bed (which made me think no one changed the sheets) and dried pee on the toilet seat- which made me think nothing in the room was clean. I called down to the desk to let them know the room wasn't clean and all the desk clerk kept saying way, "I'll make sure housekeeping doesn't charge you for the water." After he finally understood, and after a long flight, (and it was actually 3AM for us) we followed the bellman around the hotel looking for a clean room. We had reserved a room with 1 king bed, they then put us in a room with 2 beds. My husband and I don't fit in a double bed but they said that was all they had that was clean- but when I checked in and asked if the hotel was busy, they said they barely had 30% of the hotel occupied. Anyways, after 1 hour they finally found us a room that was correct and appeared clean. They didn't have a room key so they said they would slide it under the door. The next morning, we left the room but forgot something; we tried the room key they slid under the door and it didn't work. I asked a housekeeper to let us in, but she wouldn't- that was understandable, she pointed to the phone outside the elevator so I used it to call the desk. They said they would send someone up. TWENTY MINUTES LATER we finally got into the room. There was no apology or anything, in fact they tried to blame us by saying we must have demagnetized it. The customer service was awful. We decided to check out and find another hotel. Our initial reservation was for 4 nights, and even though we checked out after 1 night, the clerk didn't even ask us why. I would assume in this economy, they could use every red cent they could get.

May 5 2009 	Good place to stay in the city	We stayed here in the city for a family wedding event. It is conveniently located near so many things. The Sony metreon is right next door, lots of shopping with in an easy walk. China town and little Italy is only a 10-20 min walk away. Union square is only a few blocks away.  The hotel has nice people who amply provide information and directions all of our interactions were very pleasant. Parking is expensive but the valets are quick, helpful and very nice plus your car is safer here than in the other public lots. The omelet chef at the mission caf on the 2nd floor is great and the buffet was very good.Another plus is the Coffee Bean & Tea Company located just around the corner from the hotel.

I found the hotel is very conveniently located and everything was ideal for a business trip.Also, I got a fantastic rate through an Expedia package that I booked only two weeks prior to my stay.

Apr 1 2009 	Great Location but pricey	Recently stayed at this hotel for 4 nights on a business trip. The hotel is very large and modern. Easy walk to great food and shopping accross the street. $10 taxi or $1.50 street car trip down to fishermans warf and Alcatraz tours. Nice place to stay but was rather pricey $289 per night plus tax.

Mar 18 2009 	Friendly helpful staff in great location	The Marriott San Francisco Downtown is in a great location and this says a lot. The concierge folks outside are very attentive and seem to provide a sense of security that is necessary for the visitor from afar. The hotel also has separate high rise and mid rise elevators making it always a short wait for the next elevator and the hotel is within walking distance of all that san francisco has to offer - nightly, complimentary entertainment of the variety show variety ; 4 blocks to chinatown and maybe 30 minutes to the airport in a shuttle probably 20 in a taxi during the week. Mar 8 2009 	Great location View Lounge is incredible!	This hotel is perfectly located for accessing all San Francisco has to see. Dec 15 2008 	Nice All Around Place to Stay	We stayed at the SF Marriott on Dec 8 - 12th and had beautiful sunny days each day of our stay which made the trip that much more enjoyable. We had a 20th floor room looking to the west which was not that great of a view, but not the worst either. They did not have a king room available for early check-in, but let us get a two bed room at noon on a very busy Monday which we jumped at knowing how tired we were from the early morning flight to SF. The location is great right next to the San Francisco Shopping Centre and right on the corner of the Union Square shopping district. It is a very convenient walk just around the corner from the BART station (30 minute ride to and from the airport) and to numerous bus/trolley lines. You are also right next door to the convention center and two big movie theaters. The hotel room was a bit small, but nicely furnished. Plenty of room in the bathroom and we were to get a small fridge for the stay free from the front desk which helped. They have a mini bar, but if you remove anything you are charged an arm and a leg for it. The room was "Wired" for technology which was nice to be able to plug my iPhone into the TV to watch videos or listen to music. However, you need to bring your own cables for this. Cables are provided for a network connection and to hook your portable up to the TV screen (nice 32 inch LCD panel). The high speed internet that they advertise was incredibly slow (about 400 k download from all the test I did) and costs $12.95 per day. Food choices at the hotel are limited to a Starbucks in the lobby, an expensive steak restaurant, a bar and possibly one other small restaurant we didn't really see. There are many places very close to the hotel like Mel's Diner, Denny's, the food court at the Mall and all the other restaurants in the shopping district. A nice Whole Foods is a few blocks south of the hotel for those wanting to pick some things up. Overall it was a nice hotel to stay in with the main negatives being the internet speed, smallish room and limited food options at the hotel. Everything else was very nice and we would definitely stay there again.

Oct 12 2008 	Nice hotel - just so big!	Note that I'm a Marriott Platinum member (I stay 100+ nights/year in Marriotts so my experience might not be typical)Stayed here for the start of a 3 day holiday around California. Our conference meeting rooms were always neatly set up with water available. Our meals were tasty, and the service absolutely excellent. We loved The View, Marriott's lounge on the 39th Floor. One drawback was that Internet access in the guest rooms was an added $12.95, on top of the already big city room rates. Wireless was free on the first floor and there is a lounge area with tables off the lounge but that meant lugging the laptop down each evening. If lesser hotels (at lesser rates) can offer free internet (wired or wireless) in rooms, why couldn't the SF Marriott? I do hope they reconsider this in the future. When I called the front desk to find out my options, I was told to use the mini-bar in my room. $5 for a small bottle of water...!!!!!

May 28 2008 	Wonderful Hotel	My wife and I spent 5 nights at the Marriott in downtown San Francisco and loved everything about the hotel. The hotel lobby is spacious and beautiful and all the staff were exceptional. We had a beautiful panoramic view from our room on the 36th floor. The rooms are large, with very comfortable beds and are nicely decorated with plenty of lighting. It was a busy weekend at the hotel but I could rarely hear any conversation or T.V noise from the rooms next door. My wifes only complaint was that the bathroom toiletries weren't great. The fitness room is large with plenty of equipment. The mini bar was occupied with overpriced alcohol and soft drinks, but a portable refrigerator was provided at no charge. With a rite-aid across the street it was easy to stock up on water and drinks at a much more reasonable price. And of course the location was great...San Fran is a great walking city and the hotel is within walking distance of many great restaurants. Like others have stated parking is very expensive at the hotel. I rented a car and parked at a large parking structure across the street which was slightly cheaper at $30/day. If we weren't driving back and forth to wine country I would have relied on the BART and skipped the car rental.

May 24 2008	Excellent	Stayed for 3 nights. The rate was $199 for a larger corner room when other major downtown hotels were ranging from $260 to $425. The room was spacious, well appointed, very clean, very large desk/table to work at, plasma TV, very comfortable bed and quiet. The only negatives were the coffee maker that makes one cup at a time and doesn't keep it hot and the windows were in dire need of washing-very minor irritants and no reason to even think of not staying here.When I heard the parking was $52 a day I decided to skip a rental car which is very unusual for me. I took BART from the Airport and it stops a block from the hotel at Powell/4th station-cost was $5.35 instead of over $40 for a cab. BART is clean, fast, well run, on schedule, easy to use and makes the CTA in Chicago where I have lived my whole life seem like the armpit it is. San Franciscans do not know how good BART is unless they have taken the CTA. I highly recommend it if you stay at the Marriott.If you do not have a car and want to see Fisherman's Wharf, for $1.50 you can take the F streetcar on Market St. from the hotel. The streetcars are vintage, built in 1948, and were used in other major citiies and have been recently restored. see http://www.streetcar.org/ for info. Very nice nostalgic operation. You can get a transfer for free and use it to ride back in an hour and a half. If you go to Fisherman's Wharf eat at Cioppino's (www.cioppinosf.com) Great Italian/Seafood, large portions and our server was wonderful. It is around the corner from the beginning of the F Market streetcar lineWe ate at Mel's Diner several times. It is across the street from the Marriott and its motif is from the movie American Graffitti. If you liked the movie you will love Mel's. Breakfasts are good and reasonably priced. Service was quick. Lunch and dinner are fine but we did not like the open face turkey.so stay away from it. Don't eat in the hotel with its high prices when this is across the street

May 22 2008	Great Hotel	My 2 boys (ages 6 & 8 yrs) joined my husband in SF while he was there for business. While this is primarily a "business" hotel, we were able to enjoy the hotel as well. Not s super "family friendly" hotel...but the staff is extrememly helpful, bringing a refrigerator, microwave, & rollaway bed upon request. Could not have asked for better service!The room was a little small for the four of us, but updated, modern, and very nice.The lobby was undergoing major renovation, but we were not affected by noise or dust. Just a little bit of an "eye sore." The location was great, easy walking distance to Union Square, restaurants, and the cable car.I would stay here again.

May 18 2008 	on The outskirts...	We Stayed at the S.F. Marriott for 3 nights. We arrived at the hotel and my first impression was that it was very modern, with sleek decor, very open and Cold, and a trendy bar downstairs. The front desk girl was nice, but seemed really confused as we were using our marriott points for the 3rd night. ( we were even locked out of our room our 3rd day,so she must have Really been confused. the room itself was roomy and clean, but nothing exceptional. We never went to the Pool/spa area, but the "view bar" at the top was spectacular, if you can find a seat next to the window. A negative to this hotel is if you take the corner, it gets a litte shady, and to end on a positive note, the Bellmen are extremely friendly and helpful. We asked one of a breakfast spot one morning, and He recommened "Wich Craft" and showed us directions. (the sandwiches were fantastic!).By morning 4, I was more than happy to leave and head elsewere. This is a good 1-2 night hotel.

May 17 2008 	Nice upscale Marriott location	I recently stayed at the San Francisco Marriott for a conference. I came away with a positive impression of the property. The rooms were quite nice, definitely better than your standard business travel fare. Everything was clean and spacious. The lobby and convention/conference areas were in great shape and the staff was friendly and helpful. It was priced just about where I would expect for a hotel in downtown San Francisco (not cheap, but it wasn't outrageous either). I would definitely return here if I was visiting for non-business purposes.

May 16 2008 	Great staff great stay	We loved our stay here. The staff was wonderful. We booked on a Marriott Friends and Family discount, so we were not sure what we would get, but we had two nice connected rooms. The hotel was clean, and the staff was wonderful, everyone seemed genuinely happy. Room was nicely enhanced, flat screens, featherbeds, etc. They gave us a fridge at our request, no charge. As per prior posts, the pool seemed to have independant hours that changed at whim, and was not open when it should have been. The View Bar on the 39th floor was awesome. Kids allowed, they serve Shirley Temples, etc. Nice clean venue, fairly quiet gathering place. Seats fill early. The hotel was very convenient, BART and the Cable Cars are at the end of the block. Mel's diner is one block away, and is open 24/7 for all your dining needs. SF Centre Shopping is across the street, Union Square is 3-4 blocks away. We loved the Bay Quackers tour, worth the moolah and the tour guide was very kind and informative. This is a tour bus ride that is also a boat. Great trip, we will stay here again.

May 13 2008 	Very Nice Experience - Terrific Location	Stayed at the Marriott with a friend for four nights in early May. I had booked a fantastic price using my AAA discount. Our room, on the 17th floor, was very nice and had great views of the Yerba Buena area. Everything about our stay was handled incredibly well by the staff, and they even let us check in almost six hours early! The location could not be better - it is only a half-block from the BART/MUNI station entrance. Furthermore, Westfield Center and Union Square are incredibly close by. May 13 2008 	Very Nice Hotel	Stayed here for a couple of days. Loved the hotel and many things to see and do within walking distance or a short cab ride away. But they took the charges off. We walked to the wharf from here but it's a couple of miles so unless you like to walk I wouldnt suggest it. Too many homless people in S.F. and the parking prices are absolutely ridiculous. A major rip off to say the least. The food wasnt bad and the beer was cold. We enjoyed our stay and would stay again for sure. The Marriott beds are the best !

Apr 28 2008 	Great Stay!	Just spent two nights at the Marriott. I've been to this hotel before for brunch and other things but never actually stayed the night. Our room was perfect. Apr 19 2008 	Not that great	We stayed here for a meeting/convention at the Moscone West Convention Center. The hotel is about 2 blocks from the convention center. Apr 18 2008	Decent accomodation would come back	Located in the centre of the city and sight seeing easy to access, close to congress centre and with congress accomodations within. The only hassle i had, was with a door handle, which never worked and the person, who was supposed to come and repair it never came, it required a few complains, for it to be fixed. Apr 15 2008 	Beautiful hotel	We just returned from a 4 day trip to San Francisico. Loved the Marriott and location. A few blocks to Union Square and all of the shopping and attractions. The hotel was extremely clean. Rooms were beautiful. Loved the gym, plenty of equipment. TV's at each treadmill. My only complaint is the parking at this hotel. The rate is $53 per day! The Marriott is also a block or so next to the Westfield mall. This is a gorgeous mall with every store you can imagine. Awesome gourmet food court on the lower level. Don't miss this.
