Apr 3 2008	Trip Report - Marriott and tours	Back from wonderful trip to San Francisco. I'll try to be brief and discuss hotel, a few tips and tours.San Francisco Marriott on Fourth Street: Superb location. Just around the corner from the Westfield Mall, and loads of shopping and restaurants. Just a minute to the corner to catch the F train which runs all the way down Market Street and to Fisherman's Wharf. Just another half a block and you can catch a trolley car. The hotel's overall services were very good. Starbucks in the lobby, nice lobby bar, though about half the ground floor lobby was still under construction and walled off. Room was not ready at (early) check in so baggage check was great. Up on the 25th floor with a really nice view, the room was average, but clean and with comfy beds. I prefer room arrangements where the shower/toilet are behind the door and the sink is located outside of that area, which was not the configuration here, but the shower was still nice and the sink was wide and granite. The biggest bug that a lot of travelers complain about applies to the Marriott. Why do upscale hotels offer less in-room amenities than avg. chain hotels? $12.95 for internet access when your local Drury or Holiday In Express provides for free? And perhaps the silliest in this hotel: outrageous charges for snacks that sit on a weird magnetic tray that will charge you if you move the snack and a stocked fridge that will also charge for uses. Give me an empty fridge any day of the week. We often went around the corner and grabbed sodas and snacks from the Walgreen's and brought back to the room - kept the sodas in the ice bucket. Silly though for a hotel of this calibur to treat guests this way.Tom's Walking Muir Woods tour: Fab-U-Lous. Can't say enough about this great guy and great tour. His wife, Lisa, joined us and there was about 7-8 total in the group (including a nice couple from Scotland). Tom was knowledgeable, friendly and funny. It was great to be picked up at the hotel and even better to get to the woods early to beat the crowd and noise. We trekked on the trails for about 3 hours and it was terrific. Wine Country Tours: Took the F Train down to the Ferry Marketplace to catch the tour. Driver Brian and tour guide Jason were very nice. Jason was incredibly knowledgeable and made the trip very nice. While I discovered I'm still not a big fan of wine in general, the area is beautiful and the wine tasting and picnic stop was fun. It would have been nice to see a bit more of the production areas and wine caverns, but that's just me. Trust me, we had some fun people who just really enjoyed tasting the wine.Other stuff, Westfield Mall has a great food court in the lower level - hey don't laugh, it's not your usual food court. Andale's Mexican was yummy. Mel's diner was just on the corner of Fourth and nice for breakfast and not overly expensive - under $10. All-in-all, nice long weekend trip and it didn't hurt that the weather for northern Cal was perfect. Dress in layers and wear comfy shoes. Pack light on the way out so that you can bring home all the new stuff.

Mar 31 2008 	Crowded Rooms Friendly Staff	We spent four nights here for a conferenceit was okay overall though we had some issues, which started right at check-in. When we got up to the room we saw we had been assigned a handicapped room though we didnt request one. It was no big deal we assumedjust some bars around the toilet. After being in the room for a few hours we found the problemthe shower was designed for a wheelchair user ONLY. The showerhead height was designed for someone sitting and the hand held shower head could only be raised to a maximum height of about 4 feet 6 inches. When I called to complain reception offered to move us but by that time we had completely unpacked and there was stuff all around the room. In the end we opted not to move and sucked it up but every time we took a shower got angry about the situation. Have you ever tried to wash your hair with one hand? In addition, the water pressure on the 19th floor was dreadfulit was like being peed on, my husband joked.My experience with conference hotels such as Marriott and Hyatt is that rooms are generally sizable but this wasnt the case with our room. It was just crowded with stuff and there was not a lot of empty space in the room. The closet, for example, had the ironing board and the safe on an overly large pedestal. This stuff took up so much room that there wasnt room to open your suitcase up inside. Also, for a property that caters to business people, we found it strange that there was absolutely no free space on the desk/dresser area. There was the TV, connectivity equipment, hotel info binders and an enormous snack display (in addition to the minibar) that made your room look like a convenience store. Of course, the candy was out in the open to tempt you (see the review below about the property not losing a single opportunity to make money off guests) but it was also ugly and in the way and because of the sensors you couldnt move it. In the end I threw my coat over it so I didnt have to see itit was right in your eye line when you were sitting on the bed. For anyone traveling with kids I can see the snacks causing problems.There were some good points to the room though. I found the bed extremely comfortable. If you like a softer, pillowy mattress youll be happy here. There was a featherbed on the mattress and lots of pillows and the sheets felt nice and silky. The LG flat screen got a great picture on the digital channels and the hotel offered HBO. And the windows actually opened so you could get fresh air.We got passes to the breakfast buffet for our trouble with the shower and I have to say it was quite good. Bottomless Illy coffee and fresh squeezed orange juice, made to order omelets and waffles, all the typical breakfast dishes, some nicer stuff like smoked salmon and a huge assortment of fresh fruit. If you were paying it was pricey though, at $22 a person. A la carte dishes were also available. The onsite Starbucks and Hertz rental desk were convenient. Also, the pool looked pretty nice; a good size for an indoor hotel pool and it had a nice area for lounging. The location is in walking distance to many SF tourist attractions, shopping and the convention center.Finally, excepting our trouble at check-in, I was really impressed with how friendly all the staff were. Maybe its a west coast thing and Im used to east coast grumpiness but everybody from the servers in the restaurant, to the Starbucks employees to housekeepers and even maintenance staff, who asked if I needed help when I seemed lost, were really nice.With a rate of $139 a night I was okay with this place, it wasnt great but there were some nice aspects also. Know that if you have to come here for a conference there are other choices in the immediate area. The Hotel Palomar is right across the street, for example.

Mar 29 2008 	great location	Stayed here for a convention at a reduced rate. Room had a high quality 42 inch HD TV and was very comfortable. Excellent location close to Moscone convention center, restaurants, cable car, and shopping. I really enjoyed Yerba Buena Garden right next to it and the bar with a terrific view on the 39th floor. My only complaint is that there are three sets of elevators going to different floors which was confusing for the first day or two. Guests have to transfer elevators to get from certain floors to other floors.

Mar 23 2008 	This hotel REALLY wants your money!	I stayed here for 3 nights while attending a huge conference. The rooms were extremely comfortable and tasteful, and the bathrooms so modern, clean and big...nice towels, but their shampoo smells weird. They were doing a lot of construction in the hotel, so that made for difficult elevator use--lots of detours. Not to mention the intolerable disruption to so many of our conference presentations!My big gripe with this hotel is that it's already VERY expensive and I guess they figure only filthy rich people stay here because they try to get a few more dollars out of you at every turn. Wireless is very expensive and the signal terribly weak. To change your clothes in the locker room at the pool/health spa is 5 bucks. And most offensive of all, if you even TOUCH anything on the minibar (which includes such insults as a $4 Snickers) a SENSOR underneath it automatically charges you for it!!! So when you check out, pay attention to your final total, because you're likely to have paid out the nose for stale candy bars that you didn't even unwrap.A really great Asian fusion restaurant right around the corner is called Straits. Not too expensive and very classy. There's also a nice cheap and good Thai place a couple of blocks away.

Mar 22 2008 	Pleasant Stay at San Francisco Marriott	March 2008. I took the Amtrak Capital Corridor Train from the Sacramento Valley into the Emeryville Amtrak train station. From there an Amtrak connection bus into San Francisco. The bus stopped on Market between 4th and 5th so it was very convenient to the San Francisco Marriott, just off of Market on 4th. strret I was in town for three stay to attend a AAFA planning session. The hotel lobby was very busy, since this property also serves as convention hotel to the nearby San Francisco convention center. There were many physicians attending some type of medical convention. If you want a more quite setting, head up the hill toward properties near Union Square (Grand Hyatt, Hilton, or budget oriented Warwick Regis). My check in was smooth and I received a quiet corner room. I did not hear street noise other than a safety vehicle siren now and then.I had a great group rate of $152.00 per night. Which is a good price for San Francisco property. My room was good size with plenty of natural light and room lights. I asked for refrigerator and one was brought up fairly quick. The king bed was not the most comfortable Marriott bed but it was okay. There is small desk area and a chair. The TV had many local channels and cable channels. No golf channel.The bathroom was standard size. Water pressure was good and hot water was good too. My room was cleaned well each day.I ate at the 2nd floor inhouse restaurant for buffet Sunday breakfast. my breakfast was good, not great but a bit pricey.I recommend for more economical eating nearby...the basement of the San Francisco Shopping Center.(Where Nordstrom and Bloomingdales is located)..which has a gourmet grocery store...with many custom sections...kind of like the Whole Foods market at the basement of the Time Warner building on Columbus Square in Manhattan.Also there are many Asian fast food restaurants that are better than more food court restaurants or chains like Panda Express.At this location there was a yummy Korean BBQ and good Thai fast food places with many Asian Americans and locals eatings there as well. Good value and yummy.At the nearby Sony Meteron at Yerba Buena Gardens there is food court with several choices including the Buckhorn which has good beef and salads. There is also a good small bakerynearby the food court as well.On Market street nearby there are two Walgreen Drugstores, one West of 4th and the other East of 4th. You can get snacks, beverages, personal items and sundries at the Walgreen stores.Everyone I came into contact at the S.F. Marriott were very helpful and friendly. The front desk person was excellent and both cleaning folks were very friendly. Both left thank you notes for my daily cleaning tips.Through my experience in traveling...it is not particular chains and or brands that have greaet service (unless you go high end...Four Seasons...Mandarin Oriental...). It is more function of the General Manager of that particular property who sets the tone on how the hospitality workers behave towards clients. Hostpitality workers do not often get the best compensations pacakges, some do not get health benefits), so the savvy and skill of good people oriented Hotel GM can make all the difference to the guests who come to visit that property.I'd stay at the San Francisco Marriott again for a good rate. The only negative is that is a busy place and if you want less hectic lobby, then this might not be the property for you.I am scheduled back in San Francisco in June for HRPS Leadership Development & Succession Planning workshop. I am going to stay at the JW Marriott where the HRPS event is being held and where I can both a good group rate of $152 and HRPS rate as well. Alternative property I would consider would be the Grand Hyatt on Union Square.On my trip back home, I accidently got on the wrong train at Emeryville Station and when quickly trying to get off of train headed towards Bakersfield, I left one of my Rimowa wheeled luggage aboard. I notified an Amtrak representative on my correct train who phoned the other train to search for my luggage left on board. Several days later my luggage was delivered to my hometown train station with everything intact.Kudos to Amtrak!!!I give high recommendations to the San Francisco Marriott.

Mar 21 2008 	~Loved The View Lounge	We stayed at the San Francisco Marriott for five nights in March. The location is excellent just beside Union Square ,transport links and great shopping... The rooms are very comfortable and the hotel has good facilities as in pool, gym two lounges and the in house Starbucks came in handy. The View Lounge is great to sit in at sundown and enjoy a cocktail of your choice. On the other hand it is a big hotel with a lot of conventions and business guests so it would not be to everyones taste.

Mar 10 2008 	good and bad	Standard convention center hotel.When we booked hotel, we asked for and were promised room with city view. When we arrived, guy at front desk was being rude and said none were available. I had a feeling he was just being a lazy a-hole, so we went up to our room with the intent of talking to manager, but not in front of that guy. The room we initially received was on a low floor and had a view of a back alley. When I called down and spoke with the manager, she said plenty of view rooms were available and immediately moved us into a corner view room near the top floor. She also gave us 4 drink tickets for the bar on the top floor. Our new room had a an excellent view of the city and bay. The room was very clean and had contemporary decor.The bar at the top of the hotel has an awesome view. Mar 1 2008 	9 women 2 rooms and 1 great stay!	The women in my extended family took this year's annual Christmas shopping trip and made it a 3 day event.Parking was a bit excessive ($50/nite) but safe valet in the city is worth it for me. And do take note of other members notes on the Taxi Scandal, it got a little rediculous mostly because we needed 2 cabs to go everywhere. Ok onto the Hotel itself:Service was wonderful! we had a bellman named alfonso he took care of us for our entire stay. I have a thoery in big cities that you should always ask the bellman before you ask the concierge, you generally get better results. They got our party 2 rooms that were adjacent which was helpful, the rooms were spacious for a hotel. (be sure to check the mini-bar; we had missing items at c/i that we would have been charged for had we not mentioned it to the f/d). The Marriott Bedding was wonderful as always! The lobbys were beautiful and spacious. The Garden Terrace bar was decent but not spectacular, Bin 55 was very good. The View bar is a CANT MISS. Absolutley beautiful views. Overall my only complaint was the the parking fee, and the taxi line. Dont let those stop you though, they didnt detract from the experience.
Feb 15 2008 	Average Marriot	The Marriot is at good central location downtown, parking is very expensive and inconvenient. rooms are rather small and the bathroom is very average.

Jan 31 2008 	Nice hotel a little trouble with our reservation	We spent a short weekend at the San Francisco Marriott on our trip to the Emerald Bowl football game and thought it was very nice. It is under renovation but we didn't see or hear any construction. The lobby is large and spacious, the hallways are quiet, the carpet is new and the rooms were lovely. We stayed on the 14th floor and didn't have much of a view, but the beds were very comfortable (made me want to come home and get a new one), the bedding is fabulous and the flat screen LCD television was in high defintion. We ordered breakfast to our room the last morning and it arrived hot, fresh and on time.The only problem we had was with regard to our reservation. The hotel's options of one king or 2 doubles really didn't work for us, so we reserved a king with a rollaway. This was done online and part of the selection and reservation process, not something we typed in as a comment. When we arrived at the hotel in the middle of the night after a very long, difficult drive we were less than pleased to learn that all the rollaways were gone. If the rollaways are in fact first come, first serve as the desk clerk indicated, they should absolutely not be a part of the online reservation system. We were counting on that rollaway and really needed it. They offered us a breakfast voucher in exchange after one of the people traveling with us pressed for compensation, which was nice but still did not make our sleeping arrangements pleasant. Beware that if you reserve a rollaway you are not guaranteed to get it.

Jan 29 2008	Reliable choice	This hotel is in a nice location and the room was very clean and comfortable. The hotel staff was accomodating and check-in was a pleasant experience, even at midnight. The only complaint that I have is that the hotel is currently undergoing construction (which they did warn me about) and so getting from lobby level to your floor is somewhat of a challenge. We had to take an elevator to floor 4, walk around the corner, and take another elevator on up to higher floors. The same goes for going back down, and the wait for the elevator is sometimes long as everyone is trying to figure out how to get from point A to point B. Other than that, the experience was fine. Nothing special. Oh and also, charging for internet access in the room (not even wireless) is a bit silly, especially for a business-friendly hotel.

Jan 27 2008 	Ridiculous Valet/Taxi scam	Stayed at the Marriott SF for 2 nights and the hotel itself is not bad, nicely updated rooms, good beds and nice plasma TV's in each room, Starbucks in the lobby etc.Marriott management should be aware that they are doing an incredible disservice to their guests by allowing their valets to operate the racket that they have going on with the Taxis. As another reviewer pointed out (toasty24 review dated 10/27/07) the valets are running a common bribery racket when it comes to the Taxis here (they require the taxis to pay for airport and other fares). It took me about 2 minutes in the taxi line to catch onto this, but it wasn't just limited to so called "airport" fares. If you tip the valets you'll get a taxi right away under the guise of a "reservation" if not you'll stand in line, of course at that point they'll offer you a house car which I'm sure they're also getting kickbacks from. The taxi line takes quite a bit of time and you'll see several empty taxis drive through the valet area that refuse to pay the valets off so the valets will tell you those taxis are off duty and aren't taking any fares. The evening I was in line it was raining and I was wise to their scam so when an empty taxi drove by I said to the valet, "What's wrong, they wouldn't pay?" I then heard one of the valet's coworkers tell him that if he went on break he'd make sure we were still standing there when he got back, and we were at the very front of the line. We eventually got a taxi and we confirmed with our driver that he did indeed pay the valet $5 for the fare, he said airport fares go for 10-15. Marriott management should be aware that these employees are doing a horrible disservice to thier guests by only having the "paying" taxis available to their guests.Oh, and don't rent a car either, valet parking is $50 a night, which is outrageous no matter what city you're in.

Jan 17 2008 	Typical Convention Center Hotel	When you think of a convention center hotel, this is probably what you have in mind. However, if you're headed to a convention - especially one at the Moscone Center, this is fine place to stay.The rooms are small but clean. They have been updated recently and have comfortable beds with good bedding. The curtains are especially good at blocking the light if you like a dark room. There's a flat panel television with a good selection of digital channels. The hotel had internet available via ethernet; however, I was able to pick up a free wifi signal from outside the hotel. That was probably just luck and I didn't see a hotel wifi.The bathroom was also small, but had good, soft towels. The water pressure was fine.I checked in late and left early, so I didn't see much of the staff. However, the gentleman who checked me in was quite helpful. It was late and I was looking for a decent meal outside of the hotel. He gave me a great choice.If you're looking to have a drink in the hotel, there's a bar on the top floor with amazing views of the city.All in all, this isn't some amazing must see destination - especially for a city with so many historic hotels. However, if you need a place to spend the night, check your e-mail and then get to a convention, this will do just fine. (Also, don't take this to be condemning the hotel with faint praise. Dec 24 2007 	Perfect for a Holiday Spirit boost	This was the first time I used Priceline. Oct 27 2007 	Shameful shady bribery racket going on despite wonderful rooms	Despite a dreamy, marshmallow bed and room that meets all standards (you get what you pay for, this property aint' cheap!), I was truly disappointed with the shady operation that is blatantly going on with the employees that work there, and i want to bring this to your attention. Outside the hotel there is a taxi line for the airport. The valets will let you bypass the line and immediately you a taxi if you slip him $5 or $10. If you don't give him anything, he'll tell you to wait in line (which takes a long time). If this doesn't seem so bad yet, wait --- the TAXI DRIVER then has to surreptiously slip him $10 for the privilege of getting the long airport ride! These valets are raking in a cool $15-$20 per taxi customer, and given the high activity level of this Marriott, these guys are raking in $$$ per hour at while taking advantage of the customers and taxi drivers, all off the books.My colleague and I carefully watched this all unfold while we were outside: Valet in top hat greeting a customer, see him get a bill, and the valet "pretends" that this tipping customer has a "reservation." A taxi will pull up, and the valet will say "what's your name again?" in front of all the poor people waiting in line, and then lead the customer into the taxi. The Valet leans into the Taxi driver's window to "give directions" and slyly gets his take. When we got in the taxi, the driver admitted that he paid the valet. We asked him why, and he said he had no choice. "if I don't pay, they'll get the next taxi to pay up. We need the money and the long ride to the airport is important to our salary. The cops know about this bribery racket but haven't done anything about it." He also added that sometimes the price is $15 to get an airport ride.Now you may shrug at all this, but what does this have to do with your stay? Not much, maybe. But it says a lot about how this Marriott treats customers after they exit the property, after paying $350+ a night to stay there. It leaves a bad taste in my mouth.

Great advise given by a hotel employee.The location of the hotel is also ideal. We were about 1 block away from a location where we could catch a street car. A Walgreen's close by, which helps when you forget as many things as we did. And of course, your in the middle of a shopping mecca.Honestly, I did not want to leave. This is the first time I really felt comfortable in a hotel. I can't wait to go back and I hope anyone else who stays there has the same wonderful experience we had with the exception of the bachelorette party.

Aug 3 2007 	Love this Marriott	The rooms are big and confortable, the views are superb, the staff is helpful; what else can you ask for?We booked trough Priceline and checked in late, at about 8:00pm; therefore, I though we were going to be given the "left over " room, but was surprised by he staff's treatment. Jul 28 2007 	Great Choice	My family of four (including a 6 and 8 year old) stayed here for 5 days in late July. We had a very positive experience. The room was clean and service was efficient and unobtrusive. The gym is presently being redone, but all of the equipment is available in carpeted conference rooms on the 4th floor and this should be done in August. The pool was great for San Francisco hotels, with a large hot tub. The hotel atrium restaurant was actually a pleasant surprisethe service quick, food good and prices comparable to other local places. I found the location of the hotel to be good, mainly due to proximity to the excellent public transportation in the city. There is a Whole Foods supermarket that has prepared food 3 blocks away; the cable car and Union Square are equally close. I would strongly urge travellers to familiarize themselves with the public transportation before goingwe did not have a car and felt no need to have one. You can easily and cheaply get to all attractions with public transportation (including an inexpensive trip to the airport on BART with a station a half block from the hotel). For example, we took the trolly bus (# 30 or 46 both work) to a Giants game for $4 for the 4 of us. AT&T Park is about 7 blocks from the hotel. A cab from the airport is $35 before tip. My only complaint is that some parts of the surrounding neighborhood is a little rough around the edges, with more homeless people than I am accustomed to similar areas in Philadelphia or New York. I never felt threatened, but this did come as a surprise to me. Overall, I would definitely return.

A centralized station where you can connect your laptop, Ipod etc. Listened to our Ipod on the flat screen much of the stay.We visited the Starbucks in the lobby but didin't use any other food outlet. While I would not have expected to see such, a single phone call was all that was needed for prompt action. He too apologized and offered something to make up for the very modest inconvenience (we didn't take him up on any offer as none was truly needed). He promised a housekeeper would be up momentarily to change the sheets and again within a couple moments she appeared as well.All in all it was a very pleasant stay. Jul 19 2007 	Great Property - Great Stay	I had a great stay at this property. Good room service, great breakfast restaurant. Accomodating staff.

Jul 12 2007	This Hotel was First Class	I stayed here from Jun 28 to July 3rd and loved it! Jul 12 2007	Quite pleased except for parking fee	Enjoyed the prime location of the hotel and the plush amenities of remodeled rooms. Rate was $151/night for two weekend nights. Jun 4 2007 	Not recommended	We arrived and checked in to a room which had been used by a previous guest. They did not seemed surprised by this but did move us immediately to a clean room. The bell staff jump on you (literally) to get your luggage and we politely declined help on three occasions. They fight amongst themselves to get to the guests first so they can get a tip which is rude and intrusive. This only seems to happen in the States and I believe that gratutities should be at the guests discretion. I believe in rewarding good service. Also I do believe that it is their jobs to provide a service to guests and this service (if it is good) should be rewarded. If I want to take my own luggage then I should be able to do this without feeling that they want a tip for just opening doors or smiling. Jun 4 2007	Nice Hotel and Great Location	I found my stay at the San Francisco Marriott to be a good experience. Front desk staff was courteous. The beds were very comfortable, and the LCD TV was a nice touch. (Too bad only Discovery came in HD!)Views from the lounge on the top floor were stellar. The pool and hot tub were bustling with people, and there was a good cross section of hotel guests in the latter--not just children and seniors. (The pool was almost entirely used by children.) Also, the in-lobby snack shop was handy when we didn't feel like walking to the nearby Walgreens for a candy bar.There were five things that made the visit a 4-star experience and not a 5-star experience: 1. No TV channel guide is provided. 2. The windows are excessively dirty. 3. Free wi-fi Internet access is not available. 4. The water pipes vibrate slightly in the wall when many people take showers at once. 5. There are no personal touches, such as complimentary coffee in the lobby or mints on the pillows.I would suggest this hotel to others. In fact, I have friends that have stayed here before. The San Francisco Marriott is in a handy location for Bay Area locals: Since the hotel is south of Market, one won't get stuck in the crowds around Union Square when driving in or walking to/from BART and Muni. But all that hustle and bustle is just a couple minutes away!

Mar 22 2007 	Great Location in SF	The hotel is huge! and fairly nice. The people are polite. The lobby is big. The carpet is a little dated and makes the hallway smell a little funny. Mar 20 2007 	Great Location 	As Marriott Rewards members, my husband and I accrue points for staying at Marriott and Courtyard hotels, and recently we decided to use some points for a free night at the SF Marriott. No standing in line to check in; rooms are upgraded at no extra charge whenever available; service of all kinds is outstanding. Our room was in the corner with a gorgeous view of the city and a peek of the Bay between buildings. The king-sized bed was the second most comfortable I've ever slept in (the best was in Zagreb, Croatia--a bit far to go for a good night's sleep!). The linens were smooth and fresh. The room temperature was perfect, and although the hotel is located in the middle of one of the busiest areas of the city, it was very quiet!The bar on top has an excellent view of the city, and although the drink prices are a bit high, one is also paying for the view and the good service. We did not dine at the hotel that evening.I was only disappointed with two things: The buffet breakfast, which contained an excellent variety of dishes, was cold. I especially can't stand cold scrambled eggs, and theirs were cooler than room temperature. The meats and french toast weren't much warmer.The other shock (it is San Francisco, I realize) was the $50 per day parking fee. Wow! I was prepared for $25 or $30, but that was a bit much. I highly recommend the hotel, however, if you can stand the parking fee. You might want to walk up the street to "Sears Fine Food" (not affiliated with the dept. store) for pancakes for breakfast or to one of the bakeries nearby.

Everyone at the Marriott was friendly and very helpful. We'd highly recommend this hotel for it's clean rooms, friendly staff, location and service.

Jan 18 2007 	Simply no issues - Great Stay!	We travel to the City about once per year for a weekend get-a-way. We booked the Marriott through priceline for about $90 per night and expected the worst (as it seems many hotels treat the priceline purchasers as second-class citizens.)Our experience was entirely positive. We arrived at 9:00 a.m. on Saturday and our room was already ready . The King bed we asked for was provided and was very comfortable. The room was nothing amazing, but it was large and clean as was the bathroom. The staff were friendly and helpful at all times.The hotel is located just South of Market and is a quick walk to Union Square, North Beach and nearby museums. Jan 5 2007 	A nice stay at SF Marriott	We stayed at SF Marriott on Dec. 30 and had a wonderful experience. The room was clean, the bed was comfortable, and the room was brightly lit. The valet staff was very helpful. Look forward to staying at SF Marriott again!

Jan 3 2007 	Thank you for the room change!!	My wife and I were staying at the Marriott Downtown for December 30 and the 31st. The first night our room was adjacent to some early New Years Partyers. Jan 1 2007 	One of my favorites! Dec 27 2006	Real dissappointment	We've stayed at the SF Marriott ("Jukebox") previously without complaint but this time was really bad. Check In was extremely slow. What's worse, the bed had sharp little feathers poking through the sheets that poked us all night and given the level of the room's overall cleanliness, we wondered when the sheets had last been changed.We called the front desk after discovering the room conditions immediately, they apologized and said they'd send housekeeping right away. We went out for a "night on the town". Upon returning we found chocolates on the pillows but nothing had been cleaned. This was the worst experience we've had anywhere.

Dec 11 2006 	A Good Stay	We've just returned from a three night stay at the Mariott. The staff was very helpful and always with a smile. The room and the bathroom were very clean and the bed very comfortable. The room size, though somewhat small, was typical of the size you would get at any major city . The bar on the 37th floor offers magnificent view of the city and is well worth the ride up the elevator. The hotel is in a great location. It is near the shopping center, a 10 minute walk from China Town, a very short walk to the cable car, and around the corner from SF muesum of modern art. This hotel is a great place for both buisness and pleasure.

Nov 13 2006 	Awesome Place	We booked our room through Priceline.com and got a beautiful room for $125 a night on Friday and Saturday. Everything and everyone from the valet service to housekeeping was fantastic. The valet was full of information and was extremely kind. The bellboys were awesome. The front desk people more than went out of their way to help us. And the room was clean, newly-renovated, and extremely comfortable. The beds were to die for. The only drawback was that parking was $49 a night at the hotel. The valet recommended that we park just down the street at the Mission and Fifth Garage...we parked there for the whole weekend for $46. This hotel is close to shopping, close to the Powell/Market cable car stop, and is within footsteps to some of the world's best restaurants. Even the breakfast buffet at the hotel was great. We would stay here again any day!!!!

Nov 2 2006	A very busy place!	I came away with several impressions from my three-night stay. First, the Marriott is a very bustling and busy place. Lots of covention traffic. While I was there on vacation, the lobby was a vibrant center of activitiy. Yet once on my floor and my room, this was a great place to unwind and relax. I loved the oversized desk that overlooked the San Francisco skyline. No complaints at all with the room. The breakfast buffet was all I could ask for. Hotel location close to some good shopping and transportation to tourist attractiions. Staff was friendly and helpful. Visited the lounge on the 37th floor and it offered a great view, although a bit too crowded for me to enjoy a drink. But I can't fault it for being popular. This is really a business/conference hotel and probably is not geared to the typical tourist. Nonetheless, I was very satisfied with the accomodations and location of the Marriott. for my needs.

Oct 29 2006 	Had a great time	We got an excellent rate on Priceline for the Marriott. My husband and I stayed for three nights. Although the Marriott lacks some of the ambiance and character that the smaller boutique hotels have, it hits everything else right on the head. Customer service was great. We were promptly checked in with a smile. Our request for a king room with a view was granted without question. Our bags were brought to us in our room, which was very spacious and clean. The bathroom was very large, new, and spotless. The shower was great and we always had hot water. There is a full sized iron and ironing board in the room. The bed was very soft, there is a thick down featherbed on top of the mattress. The bed was probably one of the most comfortable I've ever slept in as far as hotels go. I didn't want to leave the bed in the morning!The hotel's location is also superb. It is on 4th and Market, right in the middle of the shopping district. The entrance to the bart/muni is literally right outside the hotel. There are buses, cable cars, and street cars right there at the intersection to take you anywhere in the city. There is a brand new upscale mall right across from the hotel which made for some exciting shopping. There is a bar at the top of the hotel on the 39th floor. My husband and I went up one night just to see the view, and it was beautiful. The bar has very tall floor to ceiling windows. We were unable to have a drink because the bar was so crowded.In summary, the hotel was great. Very clean, employees always smiling and helpful, nice spacious room with soft bed. One complaint: paying for internet access. A hotel of this magnitude should have free in room wireless service, especially with the number of business travelers they accommodate.

Oct 24 2006 	Great bar ; Great hotel ;Great city	The staff, facilities, location were AAA. SF - Cool place, cool people. And we were travelling with a five month old boy (also a jedi) and we felt very welcome.

Oct 16 2006 	Genuine rip-off	My partner and I stayed at this hotel that we booked through priceline, and it felt as if we we're treated as "lower tier" humans for doing so. The front desk manager, although apologetic and polite, stated he would call our bank and reverse the charges. The next day he promised us he did make the call. He never did, and our bank verified that no call was ever made. He told a bold faced lie right to our faces. And this was their manager! All of the front desk personnel we were in contact with really needed an attitude adjustment and/or a severe refresher course in good customer service.Unless you paid full price for one of their rooms, expect less than great customer service. The location and room itself were so-so, and as a previous poster said, they do try to gouge you for your money at every turn. Oct 16 2006 	Great customer service	I love trip advisor and was pleased to read the reviews for the Marriottt when making our decision for where to stay in San Francisco. Oct 7 2006 	Good business hotel	Recently stayed 5 nights at this hotel. Excellent location in San francisco, minutes from Union Square, and right next to new Westfield Mall/Bloomingdales! Oct 5 2006 	Best location for conferences	I stayed at the Marriot in September for a conference in the Moscone Center. San Francisco is a great place for a business trip because you can do all sorts of things without having a car, and I like walking. However, my usual hotel, the Omni, is a bit far from the Moscone Center, where most conferences are held. Depending on corpoate travel rates and the like, the Marriot may be more or less expensive than the Omni, but it's right across the street from the Moscone and the Metreon, and a short walk from the Financial District.My room on this stay was pleasantly large, clean, and well-appointed. Oct 3 2006 	I listened to Tripadvisor about this one	As usual, Tripadvisor hit the nail right on the head! This is an awesome hotel and the reviewers helped me tremendously. Actually, the man at the reception desk told my husband and me that he had "a quiet bed with two beds in it". Hmmm, maybe we should have asked how large the beds were! Aside from this minor flaw, our stay was delightful. Dan at the concierge desk is the best and everyone we came in contact with in the hotel was very professional. Sep 26 2006 	very nice	This hotel is very nice. I was just there for a very large conference. I read the reviews on this site and was a bit apprehensive by some comments. My husband was the one participating in the conference and I would basicly be on my own every day, during the day. The hotel is in a decent location (within walking distance to many places) On our way to Chinatown we were able to catch the "Love Parade" on Saturday.................interesting!! I didn't know men (only 3 but more than enough for my taste) could down a busy city street "Buck Naked". My stomach hurt from laughing so hard. Sorry guys there were no girls to follow suit. Also I got to see the motorcade of the King of Sweden pass in front of the hotel. Not everyday that you get to see that. Anyway ...back to the hotel. Our king room was big enough for the 2 of us. The bed was fantastic. Thumbs up of that one. I read on this site that a coffee maker was not supplied, so I brought my own. The pot however broke during the flight. I called the front desk and they provided us with a coffee maker. It is 2 cups only but good enough to get me going. You just have to call the front dest and ask for it and it is provided at no charge. The internet service, however, is not. The conference that we attended picked up the tab on all of our internet service. If you are attending a conference, you should ask the front desk to see if your conference is the same. If that had not been our case I would have been upset. If you are reading this Marroitt, please consider changing this policy and making it comp. The conference that we attended demanded nothing but perfection and this hotel certainly stepped up to the plate. The receptions, food and staffing were top notch.We had a terrible view of a roof but we never requested a view so no complaints here.My recommendations: Mels Drive In across the street is great for a quick breakfast or lunch. Very busy, fast service, cute "Happy Days" decor, good food at a decent price.I didn't like the Bistro across the street for dinner. I thought it was over priced and I don't like to have to ask for an explanation of the items on the menu. This resturant just left a bad taste in my mouth. If you listen to one thing that I say, go the Beard Papa's right behind the marroitt. They have the best cream puffs that you have ever tasted. I had the vanilla bean and it was out of this world. I am not a sweet eater but I heard about this place and I couldn't resist. Wow, you just have to try it for yourself to see what I mean. Over all, I would say that this was a very pleasurable stay.

Sep 20 2006 	Nice position	We were only likely to go to San Francisco once, but we had five nights, so we were unconvinced about the location of this place - it seemed away from the sights, and in a 'business district'. But, its position was perfect for us - everything except Fisherman's Wharf was walkable - and it had a four star feel for a three star price.Hotel tip: don't be scared of the top floor bar. The Golden Gate was invisible for 24 hours; ah, but when it appeared in the sunshine...- give Alcatraz a miss, and be aware the boat that takes you there doesn't go under the Golden Gate bridge- for large groups (five of us) taxis are cheaper than public transport- go the Apple shop across the road from the Marriott- some restaurants have queues outside. Regretted it.- chill out at Golden Gate park, but don't expect a children's playground - it's closed for refurbishment

Aug 28 2006 	Very comfortable stay	We took two rooms at the Marriott for three days. Our room had a beautiful nighttime view of the city and the other room overlooked the center for the arts. Both were very quiet. The bed was exceptionally comfortable. The robes provided for our use were very, very nice. All areas of the hotel were very well maintained.The lobby was lovely. It was busy, but they moved the lines very quickly and the staff was professional. Dan the concierge was EXTREMELY helpful and even gave us his personal phone number should we need to call him. (Which we did!!)The exercise facility had bikes, ellipticals and treadmills as well as weights. They had individual TVs in the treadmillsthat played movies and complimentary headsets. The fitness area also had a spa- but I didn't get a chance to use those services. (Next time.)We had a great breakfast at the hotel every morning. They made omelets to order. Try the salsa! The lobby kiosk for the Starbucks had a long line one morning, but there was an excellent coffee shop right around the corner from the hotel and another Starbucks store across Market Street. (Out the door, make a right. Another right at the corner of Market, one block up and you are there. I think it was called the Coffee Beanery. Starbucks was across Market street from the Beanery -near the Bart station.)The 15, 30 and 45 buses stop right in back of the hotel- in front of the Office Max (Office Depot? some office supply store.) They will take you up to North Beach or Chinatown.Easy access to transportation. Quiet, comfortable beds. Friendly, helpful staff. I would not hesitate to stay there again.

Aug 24 2006 	Busy Busy Busy....	Being a loyal marriott customer, I was disappointed with our visit. First the good; great bed/mattress; slept wonderfully every night! The concierge, simply excellent - offered a lot of great activities and great advice on dining. The not so good; fitness center was too crowded; 3 of 5 days I visited there were not enough machines and temperature very hot inside. This is a very busy hotel and can get quite loud. Aug 23 2006 	loved the marriott san francisco the best	it was amazing from the moment you walk in. the lobby atrium has a reastarant which i had breakfast in and that was super and i someone who never likes to eat at hotels. the rooms are big by san francisco standards and the beds are amazing also the views are great. also the view lounge is awsome with great views and a nice place to have a drink. the location couldnt be better chinatown within walking distance(must eat at oriental pearl its the best chinese youll ever eat. recommended by hotel concierge.) also union sqaure is a short walk away. this hotel was by far the best it suited all my needs for my family and we had a great time.

Aug 22 2006 	OK for the price but wouldn't do it again...	I booked a room at the SF Marriott through Priceline. I figured even if I could not be assured of the exact location I desired, I would be able to count on a decent room. Basically this is what I got. The room itself was fine, if a bit dark (we were on the 8th floor). This is a very large hotel (39 floors) with a lobby that never sleeps in an area that seems pretty busy all the time as well. Location: If you go south on Market, more to the heart of the financial district, things are nice, the sidewalks clean, and even a few trees planted here and there. If you go north on Market, the streets gets dirtier, and the stores seedier. Sixth street, which is two blocks up, is particularly "unscenic." Fourth St., where the hotel is located, appears to be the cutoff point for the neighborhood. Also, if the main entrance was on Market, rather than Fourth, it would be a big improvement. The main entrance is recessed, which is prob. appreciated when it rains, but looks dark and grungy, and the sidewalk on Fourth is narrow, which makes it crowded with all the tourists streaming in and out. Interiors: The interiors are fine, generally speaking, but one morning I walked to the elevator to find a pile of Cheetos on the floor, some of which had been ground into the carpeting. It was still there 2-3 hours later. Same thing with gum wrappers. This type of thing skeeves me out. The lobby is glitzy. There is a waterfall somewhere (used to mitigate lobby noise) and things like chandeliers and marble. However, all this being said, the basics were fine, and I could stand the shortcomings given that we had gotten a decent discount through Priceline. Still, I could not help but think everyone else passing through the lobby had gotten the same deal.In sum,the pros: *two blocks from the BART station*decent rooms with comfortable beds and nice bathrooms*friendly, professional front desk staffthe cons: *dark, recessed entrance in slightly borderline area (in my opinion)*hallways outside rooms could be cleaner (saw ground Cheetos and bits of toilet paper on the carpeting)*a bit of nickel and diming (Internet and parking--parking is $49/day) but I suppose this is to be expected at a hotel that caters to business travelers who are getting reimbursed by their companies anyway

Jul 27 2006 	LOVED the bed!	We stayed in the Marriott Downtown for 3 nights in mid-July. We really enjoyed our stay. The room was small, but very cozy, but we really loved the feather bed and pillows. As we got in the bed, we just sank into it. And we actually slept better in this bed than our own bed. In fact, we decided to order our own feather bed to put on top of ours at home. Everything was very clean and we really enjoyed our stay. We didn't have a good view, but we weren't in the room very much. They had a great breakfast buffet. It was pricey, but very good. We would like to stay there again if we ever make it to SF again.

Jul 26 2006 	Marriott for a conference	My husband and I stayed at the Marriott for a conference last week. It was a great conference property, large lobby, plenty of meeting space. Location was great for shopping- walk just a block or two and you will find a large selection of stores, ranging from Ross and Old Navy, to Macys and Nordstroms, up to Gucci and Armani. Short walk to cable car turnaround, about 8 blocks to Chinatown, 8 blocks to AT&T Park. You will have to either wait for the trolleys to get to Ghiradelli or Fishermans wharf, or take a cab- they are not within walking distance. Never a wait to get a taxi at the hotel, doormen and conceirge are a great help.

Jul 19 2006	nice hotel	clean hotel, very friendly staff,stayed for two nights, a good distance from pier 39 but the cable car ride made it worth while. You have to hit the cable car ride at certain times to avoid the lines. (for those of you who dont know a trolley is the tourist version, but the locals call them cable cars because they are actually operated on underground cables). Jul 4 2006	Fantastic Bed!	Stayed here one night and was pleasantly surprised at how nice it was. The bed was first rate! ...a foam mattress with down pad on top. The room was quiet and nicely decorated. The only drawback was they did not have a coffee machine in the room and we needed to go downstairs for coffee.

Jun 17 2006	I recommend the San Francisco Marriott	I recommend the San Francisco Marriott and would stay there again. Our room was spotless with nice furniture, new carpeting, and a granite countertop in the bathroom. There were aways two people staffing the consierge desk to help with tourism needs. The cocktail lounge on the 39th floor has a great view, and breakfast is excellent with a lot of fresh fruit. The best part is the location with great shopping and restaurants a half-block away. The trolley and cable-car stops are up the street to take you to Fisherman's Wharf.

Jun 4 2006	Not bad but slightly disappointing	This was the first hotel of a few that we stayed in whilst in the US. We arrived by cab so parking wasn't an issue and the lobby staff were very friendly. They were aware that it was our honeymoon and we had a "Deluxe Room City View" but somehow it just wasn't anything special. Although we were on the 33rd floor, the view was alright but it wasn't anything special. The room wasn't very spacious compared to other rooms we had later on in our holiday and it wasn't really clean but it wasn't dirty either. It seemed clutted and cramped. That said, the bed was fantastic and it was fairly quiet. Initially, we ate breakfast in Mel's Diner across the other side of Mission Street which was a really nice way to start the day even though we were usually there between 6 and 7 in the morning. We didn't eat during the day or the evening in the hotel but we did have drinks in the Atrium Lounge in the evening. It was very comfortable and the staff were really friendly which is not what I could say about "The View" which is a bar on the 39th floor. The view is fantastic but it only opened at 4pm and was shut by midnight. If you could get anywhere near to the bar, the bar staff were just plain rude as they couldn't care less about serving you. On the last two days, we ate breakfast in the Garden Restaurant in the hotel and that was very good both with regards to the staff and to the food. Overall, it was a dissappointment.

Jun 1 2006	Marginal for the price	For the level of hotel this was, I was a bit disappointed. The rooms were not laid out very well. The host in the concierge lounge was not helpful (we resorted to talking with the concierge downstairs with better success). The indoor pool was nice, but the chlorine was overpowering. The workout facilities were small but had all the cardio equipment--plus small TV's on each piece of equipment. Nice touch. The valet service, while expensive, was top notch and in and outs are allowed and free. The front desk and bell hops were very good. Overall, for the price, I would probably stay at the Parc 55 or other top-o-the-line hotel. When I re-read this response, it sounds negative. The hotel was not bad in any way. It was a very nice, clean, quiet hotel. However, since I travel for work on a weekly basis, I was expecting more from this high-end hotel. From that perspective, I was let down a little. This is still a very, very nice hotel with excellent amenities, a great location, and a fair price.

May 31 2006	Great Hotel	Just returned from 3 days stay at the San Francisco Marriott Downtown.LOCATION: Its a nice hotel in SOMA close to MarketStreet and Museum of Modern Art. The neighborhood is nice and close to Market Street shopping, Muni train stationand many tourist attractions and is quite safe even late at night.ROOM: The room that was offered to me was anon-smoking disabled access room, so your roommight differ from these description about the room.The view of the city and MOMA was great from theroom. There is a separate high floor elevator thatprovides quick access to high floors with as fewstops as possible. The room and bathroom was very spacious. Fortunately, there are quite a few 24 hourconvenience stores steps away from the hotel onMarket street.The carpet and furniture was little worn, but the linensand comforters were fresh and new.STAFF: The front desk staff was very nice and gave mea high floor room with view. Housekeeping staff wascourteous as well. Didn't have a chance to talk with concierge services - so can't comment on that.FACILITIES: The room has high speed wired internet access available for an extra $12.95. Room hasa TV with number of US channels including HBO and Starz.To SUM UP, this is a great hotel with good service. I wouldrate it 3.5 stars.
